text: right here is where I want to put the
headphone jack
Scottie Allen is an engineer and
filmmaker who posts videos modifying
smartphones
he lives in Shenzhen in China and was
inspired by the city's busy electronics
markets to have a go at modding his own
devices millions of people have watched
him at a working headphone jack - the
iPhone 7 after Apple removed it and his
latest experiment is adding wireless
charging to an old phone obviously you
shouldn't attempt this unless you know
what you're doing you could wreck your
phone and there are safety risks i sat
down for a video call with Scotty to
talk about what phone modders in
Shenzhen called DIY what inspired the
headphone jack project was one this
frustration with not having the
headphone jack anymore I have some nice
in-ear headphones that I still really
love and carrying around an adaptor
didn't strike me as very much fun and I
really wanted to see if it was possible
what was the process of putting a
headphone jack back into the iPhone like
the process was way more involved and
way more frustrating than I possibly
could have imagined when I started
taking the photo part and looking at
what was in that space where the
headphone jack was I thought what I was
gonna say is there is no space see here
see this is the thing that they put in
that space where the headphone jack
would be except that when I did that it
was sort of a relatively useless piece
of plastic and it made me realize wait a
minute I think there actually is enough
space to put a headphone jack here in
the end I couldn't find a reason why it
wasn't possible and so I ended up
succeeding and then I got a message from
a Chinese fan who said I built a
wireless charging add-on for the iPhone
do you want to come see it that really
was our kind of collective process of
debugging that and making it possible
for other people to do that when you
modify your phone's what's the worst
thing that's happened the worst thing
that happens and this happens
semi-regularly unfortunately is that I
break a logic board which is sort of the
heart of the phone it's like I'm the
motherboard in a computer because of
that it makes up the bulk of the price
of the phone how much do you think your
projects have cost you in total I it's
in the thousands I think it's probably
less than 10,000 still but I don't I
wouldn't really want to calculate it
close enough to figure out what it hurts
to think about that is there anything
left that utilize put into a phone what
do you want to get in there next you
know there are a lot of things that
viewers and fans have suggested can you
add more storage can you add more memory
can you add an SD card I'm very careful
to choose which projects I tackle based
on which ones I think are possible and
not everything is equally possible so
one I get a lot is can you add a touch
ID button to an iPhone X and that sounds
pretty close to impossibly hard why do
you think people try and add features
onto old phones cost-saving measure
the real answer is because it's fun
because I'm curious because it's a great
way to learn about sort of the
cutting-edge devices I really enjoy sort
of telling the stories of being an
engineer trying to figure this stuff out
the goal is is not to have that like end
working perfect phone at the end it's
it's the journey
